div.head: OUR LONDON LETTER.
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
London, October 11.

A ceremony which cannot fail to be impos- ing has been arranged for Wednesday, October 18, when the Kina-, who is to be accompanied, by the Queen, will open Kingsway and Aid- wych, tho broad now thoroughfares construe tel by the London County Council on the . Holborn to Strand improvement. The order of the proceedings has been approved by his Majesty, and nothing now retrains but to make the final preparations. The royal procession will comprise four carriages, the first three for the suite and the last fer the King and Queen, who will be attended by a cavalry escort The route is to be by way of the Mall, Marlborongh-yard, Pall-mall, Pall-mall Bast, Dancannon-street, and the Strand to the western end of Aldwych, and thence through the new street to its junction with Kingsway, where a ddi» is to be constructed. At this point their Majesties will be met by the chairman of the council ; (Mr. B. A. Cornwall), the vice and deputy ' chairmen, the chairman of the Improvements Committee (Mr. J. Allen Baker), the vice- , chairman and members of the committee, and , the clerk of the counoil (Mr. G.^i Gomme). When the King and Queen have taken their i seats on the day, Miss Bernice Cornwall will present a bouquet to her Majesty, after which the chairman of the council will read an ad- dress to his Majesty on behalf of the London County Council Then will come the most important item of the programme. After re plying to the address, the King will be pre- sented with a gold key. with which he will unlock the gates erected temporarily to dose the thoroughfares, and will then declare Kings- way and Aldwych open for the use of the public, a declaration which will be received with a flourish of trumpets.
Subsequently their Majesties will be asked to accept bound copies of a descriptive account of the improvement, and to sign the council's record of their presence on the occasion of the opening.

Before returning to Buckingham Palace the royal procession will drive right along the new thoroughfare, passing the platform opening to the new underground tramway and the site of the School of Arts and Crafts, which is to be built by the Council in Kingsway. Their Majesties will cross Holborn and proceed right to tho end of the improvement, through Southampton-row and thence through Vernon- place, Hart-street, Oxford-street, Regent street, Waterloo place, and so back to the Palace. The details as to what guards of honor are to be mounted are not settled as yet, but troops will line both sides of the new street and its approaches, probably being furnished from the London garrisons.

At the meeting of the London County Coun- cil to-morrow, the General Purposes Committee will bring up a report with regard to the opening of Kingsway and Aldwycb. They will state that they are carefully considering the arrangements to be made in connection with the opening ceremony, and have pot forward an estimate of £5,000 to meet the necessary expenses. They recommend that the estimate be approved and authorised. In connection with the same matter, the Finance Committee will submit that they have received an esti- mate from the General Purposes Committee for the outlay of £5,000, and have no observations to oiler on the matter. Mr. Russell 8poke‘ will recommend that the matter be referred back for further consideration.

At the meeting of the Holborn Borough Council on Wednesday. Councillor Keen will move a motion asking the County Council to change the name of that portion of Southamp- ton Row between Theobalds-road and High Holborn to Kingsway before the day of the opening ceremony.M

On January 25 next Admiral Sir John Fisher reaches the age of sixty.five, and would, consequently, be retired under the age rule did circumstances permit But it is out of the question that an officer called to the all important post of First Sea Lord to carry out a great policy of reform should be obliged to quit bis post after only some sixteen months' service—long before his work is accomplished. Despite the fact, therefore, that the number of Admirals of the Fleet is already shove the establishment, we may confidently expect to see Sir John promoted to that rank by special O der in Council. In the interest country, it is greatly to be hoped that be will see his way to accept the promotim, and to continue in office. But it is wort a while to inquire st what rate a private firm would estimate the value of Sir John Fisher's »«i and what a grateful country thinks adequate remuneration for them. The Portsmouth com mand. which be relinquished to become First Sea Lord, is worth £4,000 a year. The salary of b-s pie ent office is £2,500. No one doubts for one moment that Sir John Fisher ie con- tent to be in the position in which be can best serve his country, even though thereby he incurs a pecuniary loss ; but this is niggardly treatment on the part of the country, and a poor inducement to officers of ability to con- tinue in the public service. There is, I believe, precedent in the case of Lord Hood of Avalon for making a grant in recognition of distinguish- ed service. Surely, when Sir John Fisher is asked to continue his work, it would be a fitting time for a simile r recognition of services almost unparalleled to be made to him. No one can doubt that the proposal of a grant would meet with ready acquiescence. Princess Christian has greatly gratified the Aberdonians by visiting their city twice within a week, each time in the interests of charity, the first time for the purpose of seeing the infirmary, where she displayed a knowledge of nursing detail and hospital administration that somewhat surprised her guiders . She also on that occasion visited Lady Cathcart’s Training Institute for Girls. Lord Aberdeen was wearing the dress of a Highland chief—a kilt of Gordon tartan, grean oat, and Scotch bonnet with the clan badge of the Gordons—when he presided at the meeting of the Soldier's and Sailors' Aid Society at Aberdeen the other day. which the presence of Princess Christian made such a splendid success. That Lord and Lady Aberdeen are immensely popular in the city from which they take their name is evident to eve* the casual visitor, for both have the heartiest greeting whenever they appear in public. Lord Aberdeen was an admirable chairman at the med'ing. tactful and genial, and with kindly and appreciative words for all who help the work of the society of which he is president, especially for its able secretary, the Hop^ Mrs. Forbes, of Brux. Lady Aberdeen had quite an ovation when she appeared on the platform with General Sir Charles Tucker. She is president of the Aberdeenshire branch of the Soldiers' and Sailors' Families Association, so that, as Lord Aberdeen jocularly remark; d, there is a sort of diplomatic matrimonial alliance between the two societies, ai d they are not likely to quarrel.

Lady Aberdeen, who is just now almost constantly with her daughter Lady Marjorie Sinclair at Tarland, was looking remarkably handsome in a gown of mauve cloth with beautiful sables and mauve ‘oque. Before the meeting she was talking gaily with General Tucker, whose uniform made a variety on the dress of the civic fathers present to wel- Come e the Princess. Sir Charles was one of Lady Gordon Cathcart's many distinguished guests at Cluny. Castle to meet Prince's Christian and her daughter.

We should like to be more folly informed as to the reasons which have led General Booth to abandon, for the present, his wide and far- reaching scheme of emigration to Australis. That he should have encountered a certain amount of passive resistance to his ideals in certain of tho States cannot have been a shock to one so well versed in men and politics. Wo deplore the existing opinions by which the Australasian democracy is largely swayed, for they ore in their more pronounced manifesta- tions, as childishly wrong headed an they are self-destrnctive. Bat we do not despair of a change of mind. Nor is it easy to acknow- ledge that a known state of affairs is a suffi- cient bar to an experiment which promised so well that it received the hearty support of public opinion in England and Mr. Deakin' warm approval. There may be misconception as to the quality of the Army's emigrants. There should be easily removed. There may be other obstacles of a temporary nature. But we hope that the large plan is only deferred, and that the ‘ small contingents" will prove an earnest of future success.

If we accept the torching of Dr. Plehn, a speaker at the German CoWal Conference, we shall attribute the brutal excesses of German and Belgian officials when set to govern white men to 'tropencholer,” or tropi- cal frenzy. An official with tropical frerrv, says Dr. Plehn, is not responsible for his actions, however criminal they may be. Tho disease gets hold of him jnst like creeping paralysis, an affliction with which it has much in common. It is true that experience shows the deterioration of many white men under the enjoyment of unlimited authority. Bat a tortured native of the Congo or German South- West Africa does not derive much consolation from the statement that his woes were inflict- ed by a madman, nor is the star cast upon the white races mitigated by the same knowledge We most beware of condoning brutality by the excuse that it was inflicted daring temporary insanity. Colonisers are called on to fight their own lower dispositions as well as the more easily conquerable obstacles with which they are faced. Unless they can master themselves as well as the natives they are not worthy the name of pioneers of civilisation.

The rapture of an Englishman by brigands in the neighbourhood of Monastir is a warning to travellers not to trust themselves in that Part of Turkey without a proper esoort. The wretched incapacity of the Turkish administra- on makes such a precaution absolutely neces- Sary, though, as a matter of fact, in most of these cases-the brigands are perfectly well- known, and could be suppressed with very little trouble. A British Consol at Salonica, from which place the news of this capture comes, years ago expressed his conviction that with half a squadron of horsemen and leave to Use them in his own way he would clear the whole province of brigands in a fortnight In the meantime, it remains really dangerous for travellers who are supposed to be worth a ransom.

It is not an easy matter to determine quite who among the bishops would make the best President of a Church Congress, for in what- ever part of the conn try' these annual eccle- Siastical gatherings are held there is an able and scholarly man ruling over the spiritual fortunes of that diocese in which the Congress town is situated. Weymouth being in his diocese, the Bishop of Salisbury has been call- ed upon to perform the presidential functions at this year’s meetings. Dr. Wordsworth's father was the bishop of- that name, and he is a great-nephew of the poet.

A glance at any account of the Bishop’s life shows that he has had quite a remarkable career. After leaving Oxford he went as master to Wellington College, but war soon transferred to Brasenose as tutor. His scholar- ship and training gave him several import- ant positions in the Church, Dr. Wordsworth having interested himself in a variety of sub- jects of a literary and religious character. Latin classical literature, the Latin New Test- mont, the Education Question, the Old Ca- tholic Movement, the Colonial Churches, the Eastern Churches, liturgical questions, and Church History and Doctrine are some of the subjects in which he takes a keen interest The Bishop of Salisbury is* one of the most travelled of prelates, having been all over the Colonies, in most parts of Europe, and visited several of the Patriarchs of the Eastern Church at Constantinople, Jerusalem, Alexandria, and Damascus.

Justice would not suffer, and society would benefit from an extension of the spirit of sympathy displayed by a detective and a magistrate at Middlesex Quarter Sessions. The prisoner was an exconviot who had gone far towards living down a reputation for going on burglarious expeditions with a loaded revolver in his pocket and shooting at policemen. Por mx years he had been "going straight" had married and proved excellent husband and father, had worked bard and honestly to keep together bis little home. Then being pressed for money, he had stolen a quantity of wood. The usual course with’ that man would have been to bring the criminal part of his record against him, and send, him to gaol again for a long period. Thereby he would have been im- pressed with tho futility of trying to "go straight,” and would have relapsed into bis former way of life, a misery to himself and a terror to other people. The detective in charge of the case happened, however, to be an Officer who could appreciate even an exconvict’s better side. He told the bench the best be could of the mao, and the bench approved his action by giving the prisoner another chance. If notice of such practical sympathy' were shown, we might hear less of the impossibility of a lost character being regained.

The experiences of Mr. Mark Hambourg, the pianist, in the colonies, have been precisely similar to that of many other virtuosos. He declares ho found the appreciation of classical music extraordinary and gratifying. Mr. Ham- bourg never tried to play popular music, and was never compelled to in order la draw audiences. Nothing exasperates the colonial so much— whether in South Africa, Australasia, or Canada—as to be tried with too popular a per- formance of any kind, or to be suspected of being incapable of appreciating the classical. Audiences take art and culture seriously ; a very popular vocalist who toured the Empire not long ago with surprisingly little suocess, only discovered after months that this was due to the fact he bad been singing ballads. Lon- doners who are sure of their position in the world of art, and only want to be entertained, make one of the most easily pleased audiences in the world.

Having always expressed the view that sooner or later sixpenny fares would become a necessity of the cab industry, I welcome the announcement of the London Cabowners’ Federation that they intend once more to try the experiment, and in association, too, with the taxameter. Cabby has always set his face against the sixpenny minimum, but, consider- ing the ever-increasing competition now accen- tasted by the motor omnibuses and the electrified underground, he will be foolish indeed if be again resolutely sets his face against this reform It is for the short journey that the cab is now so much needed, and when the distance can be covered for sixpence it Is certain the use of cabs will be largely increased. All that the system needs is a fair trial.

div.head: NEST BUILDERS OF THE SEA.
div.p: SOME INTERESTING FACTS

Writing on the subject in the New York ‘Tribune," Mr. C. P. Holder wye that a few year ago some farmers in the vicinity of the Saco River, in sailing over it, discovered what appeared to be an artificial dam of stones, and it was suggested that at an early date the natives of the region had been seised with a desire to dam op the river and had started a breakwater, bat had been forced to abandon it The structure was fifteen or twenty feet in length, three or four in height, and two or three feet through. The theory of the human origin of the work held for year; but finally one day an inquisitive man went to one of the farmers a man who seemed fond of plants, fishes, and animals of all kinds, and it was not long before he heard the story and had examined the stone dam or breakwater, and bad a well-defined plan of it on paper. Not only this, he spent hours on the river floating over the curious structure, studying it from all points. Finally, one day he announced that he had learned how it was made and who the builders were. This aroused much interestamong the neigh- hours, and not a little laughter when he stated that the so-called dam was made by lamprey eels, and was their-nest, a castle, a stone for- tress for the protection of their young. While the nest of the stone toter or sucker was a mountain-peak, a pile of stones, this was a miniature mountain-range, a breakwater fifteen feet long by three in height, each stone of which had been carried to the spot by the builders. No little intelligence was displayed by the lampreys in their work. Some of the stones that composed the nest were as large as half a brick, and the observer saw the fishes bringing them, two eels being fastened to each stone. Such material was sought up the river, doubtless so that the current could be employ- ed. The lamprey is an eel with a peculiar sucker-like mouth. Two fishes would swim about till they found a large stone : they then would fasten their mouths to it, and by squir- ming lift it from the bottom, and the moment it was clear the swift current would sweep them down the stream in the direction of the nest. If the weight of the stone carried them to the bottom, the action would be repeated indefinitely, or until they wore carried or swept over the nest, when the load would be dropped. Individual stones were brought by single Gibes almost always in tbe same way, the tail being held upward or vertically to offer the greatest resistance to the current, which at this locality was swift. How long the nest had been in course of erection no one knew, but doubtless a bomber of years were required to produce a structure that mort bare weighed several tons. In their home or neat-building the fishes recall the birds, and in some instances the resemble no o is pronounoed, a notable one being the common stickleback, the several varieties building complicated and birdlike nests. The stickleback is a pugnacious little creature, with an armament of spines that makes it dreaded by larger fishes. Nearly, if not all, make nests, and when kept in an aquarium their movements may he watched from day to day. . . When the material collected teemed to suit the builder—the male fish—be would life it about, change it after some architectural plan of his own, then rud- denly butt into the mass bead first and force his way into it with a wriggling motion,-rub- bing himself against it, and going over it with the rubbing motion, until after several days an object was seen, of irregular egg-shape, with an orifice about the site of the fish through it This had been shaped and moulded by the nest-builder. . . At last the middle portion is large enough so that the stickleback can poise or rest in it, an 1 then the nest is com plete. This is the type of nest most common, and hundreds may be seen in localities effect ed by these fishes. Others are suspended from twigs that have become water-logged and suspended between twigs or branches, or are placed beneath projecting lodges of rock. When completed, the fish bunts up his mate and drives or escorts her to the neat and present# the mansion to her. She accepts -it, deposits her eggs or spawn in the Interior and imme- diately deserts them, leaving them to the mercy of the male, who having been the house-builder now becomes the nurse.
